0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans; Prophylaxis - Venous thrombosis; Prophylaxis: short-term prophylaxis: initial dose, 100 to 120 IU/kg IV followed by 3 doses at 60 to 80 IU/kg IV every 6 hours; maintenance dose, 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 6 or 12 hours; maintain a trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of prophylaxis
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans; Prophylaxis - Venous thrombosis; Prophylaxis: long-term prophylaxis: 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 12 hours; maintain a trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of prophylaxis
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans - Venous thrombosis: initial: 100 to 120 IU/kg IV; followed by 3 doses at 60 to 80 IU/kg every 6 hrs; after the initial dose adjust dose to a target peak protein C activity of 100%
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans - Venous thrombosis: maintenance: 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 6 or 12 hours; once the acute episode resolves, maintain trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of treatment

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans; Prophylaxis - Venous thrombosis; Prophylaxis: (neonatal and pediatric patients) short-term prophylaxis: initial dose, 100 to 120 IU/kg IV followed by 3 doses at 60 to 80 IU/kg IV every 6 hours; maintenance dose, 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 6 or 12 hours; maintain a trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of prophylaxis
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans; Prophylaxis - Venous thrombosis; Prophylaxis: (neonatal and pediatric patients) long-term prophylaxis: 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 12 hours; maintain a trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of prophylaxis
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans - Venous thrombosis: (neonatal and pediatric patients) initial: 100 to 120 IU/kg IV; followed by 3 doses at 60 to 80 IU/kg every 6 hrs; after the initial dose adjust dose to a target peak protein C activity of 100%
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans - Venous thrombosis: (neonatal and pediatric patients) maintenance: 45 to 60 IU/kg IV every 6 or 12 hours; once the acute episode resolves, maintain trough protein C activity level above 25% for the duration of treatment

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans; Prophylaxis - Venous thrombosis; Prophylaxis
  • Protein C deficiency disease - Purpura fulminans - Venous thrombosis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Meningococcemia - Purpura fulminans

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant anticoagulant use; increased risk of bleeding episodes
  • hypersensitivity, history or serious allergic reaction to mouse proteins and/or heparin
  • human plasma derivative; infectious agent risk, including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • immunocompromised patients; risk of infection with human parvovirus or hepatitis A transmission
  • low-sodium diet; the maximum daily dose of Ceprotin(TM) contains over 200 mg of sodium
  • pregnancy; risk of fetal infection with human parvovirus or hepatitis A transmission
  • renal impairment; risk of sodium overload
  • thrombocytopenia, heparin-induced; Ceprotin(TM) contains a trace amount heparin
  • suspected product-related infections or other adverse reactions should be reported by the healthcare provider to Baxter Healthcare Corporation at 1-866-888-2472 or to the Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Once activated, protein C (a precursor of a vitamin K-dependent anticoagulant glycoprotein) inactivates the activated forms of factors V and VIII with subsequent reduction in thrombin formation. Other effects include profibrinolytic effects

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute with sterile water for injection at room temperature
  • use within 3 hours after reconstitution
  • filter the content with a filter needle before administration
  • administer at room temperature
  • for children less than 10 kg, the maximum rate of infusion is 0.2 mL/kg/minute; for children greater than 10 kg and adults the maximum rate of infusion is 2 mL/minute.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• protein C activity levels before and during treatment; during acute thrombotic events, measure protein C activity immediately before the next dose until the patient is stabilized
  • target peak protein C activity at 100% during acute episodes and maintain trough protein C activity level above 25% after resolution of acute episode or for prophylaxis
  • coagulation parameters.
  • sodium concentration.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a remote risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare professional.
  • Inform patient that the quantity of sodium in the maximum daily dose of Ceprotin(TM) exceeds 200 mg. Instruct patient to follow a low-sodium diet.
  • This drug may cause rash, itching, and lightheadedness.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of a hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Ceprotin(TM) contains trace amounts of heparin.
